# What is DWI ?

Diffusion Weighted Imaging (DWI) is an MRI technique that measures the diffusion of water molecules in biological tissues.

- **Principle**: Uses magnetic field gradients to sensitize the MRI signal to water diffusion
- **Key parameters**: b-values and b-vectors


# DWI Pipeline
```{dot}
//| label: fig-dwi-pipeline
//| fig-cap: "Overview of the DWI Pipeline."
digraph DWI_Pipeline {
  rankdir=LR;
  node [style=filled, fillcolor=lightblue, fontcolor=black, fontsize=10];
  edge [fontsize=10];

  subgraph cluster_acq {
      label="Acquisition";
      style=filled;
      color=lightblue;
      MRI [label="MRI\nScanner"];
      Params [label="b-values &\nb-vectors"];
      Gradients [label="Apply\nDiffusion\nGradients"];
      Signal [label="Signal Images"]
      MRI -> Gradients;
      Params -> Gradients;
      Gradients -> Signal;
  }

  subgraph cluster_prep {
      label="Preprocessing";
      style=filled;
      color=lightgreen;
      Eddy [label="Eddy Current\nCorrection"];
      Motion [label="Motion\nCorrection"];
      Denoise [label="Denoised\n Signal Images"];
      Signal -> Eddy -> Motion -> Denoise;
  }

  subgraph cluster_rec {
      label="Reconstruction";
      style=filled;
      color=lightsalmon;
      DTI [label="DTI"];
      CSD [label="CSD"];
      GQI [label="GQI", fillcolor=yellow, shape=box];
      Denoise -> DTI;
      Denoise -> CSD;
      Denoise -> GQI;
  }

  subgraph cluster_ana {
      label="Analysis";
      style=filled;
      color=lightcoral;
      Tractography [label="Tractography"];
      FA [label="FA\nMaps"];
      ODF [label="ODF\nVisualization"];
      DTI -> FA;
      CSD -> Tractography;
      GQI -> Tractography;
      Tractography -> ODF;
  }
}
```
